canonical_explanation.text: Synthetic fibres are man-made fibres prepared by chemical processing of petrochemicals. They are polymers, which are large molecules made up of many repeating small units called monomers. Common synthetic fibres include rayon (made from wood pulp, also called artificial silk), nylon (the first fully synthetic fibre, very strong and elastic), polyester (wrinkle-resistant, used widely in clothing — PET is a popular form), and acrylic (resembles wool, lightweight and warm). Plastics are also polymers that can be moulded into desired shapes. They are classified into thermoplastics (which can be softened and remoulded on heating, like PVC and polythene) and thermosetting plastics (which cannot be remoulded once set, like bakelite and melamine). While synthetic materials have many advantages such as durability and low cost, they are mostly non-biodegradable and cause environmental pollution. The 4R principle — Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Recover — helps manage plastic waste.
rules: Synthetic fibres are man-made from chemical substances (petrochemicals).
A polymer is a large molecule made of many repeating units called monomers.
Rayon is made from wood pulp and is called artificial silk.
Nylon is the first fully synthetic fibre; it is strong, elastic, and lightweight.
Polyester (e.g., PET) is wrinkle-resistant and widely used in clothing.
Acrylic resembles wool and is used as a wool substitute.
Thermoplastics can be remoulded on heating (e.g., PVC, polythene).
Thermosetting plastics cannot be remoulded once set (e.g., bakelite, melamine).
Plastics are non-biodegradable and persist in the environment for years.
The 4R principle (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Recover) helps manage plastic waste.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is called artificial silk?
questions.explanation_correct: Rayon is called artificial silk because it is made from wood pulp by chemical treatment and has a silk-like appearance and feel, though it is not a fully synthetic fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon, polyester, and acrylic are all synthetic fibres but none of them is known as artificial silk. Rayon is the fibre called artificial silk because it resembles silk in texture and appearance, and is made from natural cellulose (wood pulp) through chemical processing.

questions.question_text: What was the first fully synthetic fibre?
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon was the first fully synthetic fibre, developed in 1931. It is made entirely from chemical substances without using any natural raw material, unlike rayon which is made from wood pulp.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rayon is not fully synthetic as it is made from natural wood pulp. Polyester and acrylic were developed after nylon. Nylon holds the distinction of being the first fibre made entirely from chemical substances (coal, water, and air) without any natural raw material.

questions.question_text: Which synthetic fibre is commonly used as a substitute for wool?
questions.explanation_correct: Acrylic is used as a substitute for wool because it is lightweight, warm, and has a soft texture similar to natural wool. It is also cheaper and more durable than wool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rayon resembles silk, not wool. Nylon is known for its strength and elasticity. Polyester is wrinkle-resistant and used in clothing. Acrylic is the synthetic fibre specifically designed to resemble wool in texture and warmth.

questions.question_text: From which raw material is rayon made?
questions.explanation_correct: Rayon is made from wood pulp, which is a natural source of cellulose. The cellulose is chemically treated and dissolved, then regenerated as fibres, which is why rayon is sometimes called a regenerated fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rayon is not made from petroleum, coal tar, or natural gas. It is made from wood pulp, which provides natural cellulose. This cellulose is chemically processed to create rayon fibres, making it a semi-synthetic fibre.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a property of synthetic fibres?
questions.explanation_correct: Synthetic fibres are NOT easily biodegradable. They persist in the environment for a very long time because microorganisms cannot easily decompose them. Durability, wrinkle-resistance, and quick-drying are actual properties of synthetic fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Synthetic fibres are indeed durable, wrinkle-resistant, and quick-drying. However, they are not easily biodegradable — this is one of their main disadvantages. Synthetic materials take hundreds of years to decompose, causing environmental pollution.

questions.question_text: Which synthetic fibre is known for being wrinkle-resistant and is widely used in clothing?
questions.explanation_correct: Polyester is known for being wrinkle-resistant and is one of the most widely used synthetic fibres in clothing. PET (polyethylene terephthalate) is a well-known form of polyester used in fabrics and bottles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While all these are synthetic fibres, polyester is specifically known for its wrinkle-resistant property. Rayon resembles silk, nylon is known for strength and elasticity, and acrylic is known for warmth similar to wool.

questions.question_text: Why are nylon ropes preferred over cotton ropes for rock climbing?

options.text: Nylon ropes are stronger, more elastic, and lightweight

questions.explanation_correct: Nylon ropes are preferred for rock climbing because they are very strong, elastic (can stretch without breaking), and lightweight compared to cotton ropes. These properties make them safer and easier to carry for climbing activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The primary reason is not cost but performance. Nylon is stronger, lighter, and more elastic than cotton. Nylon is not biodegradable and does not absorb water easily — these are actually advantages for outdoor use as the rope stays light and does not rot.

questions.question_text: A student wants a fabric that looks like silk but is cheaper. Which fibre should the student choose?
questions.explanation_correct: Rayon is called artificial silk because it has a silk-like appearance and feel but is much cheaper than real silk. It is made from wood pulp and provides an affordable alternative to natural silk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon is strong and elastic but does not resemble silk. Polyester is wrinkle-resistant but not silk-like. Cotton is a natural fibre. Rayon is the correct choice because it is specifically called artificial silk due to its silk-like look and feel at a lower cost.

questions.question_text: Which type of plastic can be remoulded on heating?
questions.explanation_correct: Thermoplastics can be softened and remoulded repeatedly on heating. Examples include PVC (polyvinyl chloride) and polythene. They do not undergo any chemical change during heating and can be reshaped multiple times.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermosetting plastics, bakelite, and melamine cannot be remoulded once set. Thermosetting plastics undergo a permanent chemical change on heating and become hard permanently. Thermoplastics are the type that can be repeatedly softened by heating and reshaped.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a thermosetting plastic?
questions.explanation_correct: Bakelite is a thermosetting plastic that cannot be remoulded once it is set. It is used for making electrical switches, handles of utensils, and other items that need heat resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polythene, PVC, and polypropylene are all thermoplastics that can be remoulded on heating. Bakelite is the thermosetting plastic in this list — once moulded and cooled, it retains its shape permanently and cannot be resoftened.

questions.question_text: What is the main difference between thermoplastics and thermosetting plastics?

options.text: Thermoplastics are harder than thermosetting plastics
Thermoplastics can be remoulded on heating, thermosetting plastics cannot

questions.explanation_correct: The main difference is that thermoplastics can be softened and remoulded repeatedly on heating, while thermosetting plastics undergo a permanent chemical change and cannot be remoulded once set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermosetting plastics are generally harder, not the other way around. Neither type is biodegradable. Both types are poor conductors of electricity. The key distinguishing feature is that thermoplastics can be repeatedly heated and reshaped while thermosetting plastics cannot.

questions.question_text: Why is melamine used for making floor tiles and kitchen utensils?

options.text: Because it is a thermoplastic and can be easily reshaped
Because it is a thermosetting plastic that resists heat and fire

questions.explanation_correct: Melamine is a thermosetting plastic that is highly resistant to heat and fire. These properties make it ideal for floor tiles (which need to be durable) and kitchen utensils (which need to withstand high temperatures).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melamine is not a thermoplastic — it is a thermosetting plastic. It is not biodegradable and not typically transparent. Its heat resistance and fire-resistant properties make it suitable for kitchen use and flooring applications.

questions.question_text: PET is a very popular form of polyester. What is PET commonly used for?
questions.explanation_correct: PET (polyethylene terephthalate) is commonly used for making bottles for drinks and water, as well as clothing fabrics. It is lightweight, strong, and wrinkle-resistant, making it versatile for both packaging and textiles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrical switches are typically made from bakelite (thermosetting plastic). Car tyres are made from rubber. Rubber bands are made from natural or synthetic rubber. PET, a form of polyester, is widely used in bottles and fabric manufacturing.

questions.question_text: What does the term 'biodegradable' mean?

options.text: A material that can be recycled
A material that can be decomposed by microorganisms
A material that dissolves in water

questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable means a material that can be broken down or decomposed by microorganisms (like bacteria and fungi) into simpler, harmless substances. Examples include paper, food waste, and cotton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biodegradable does not mean recyclable, water-soluble, or easily combustible. It specifically refers to the ability of a material to be decomposed by living organisms (microorganisms) into natural, harmless substances over time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-biodegradable material?
questions.explanation_correct: A polythene bag is non-biodegradable because it is made from a synthetic plastic (polyethylene) that cannot be easily decomposed by microorganisms. It can persist in the environment for hundreds of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paper, cotton cloth, and vegetable peels are all biodegradable — they can be decomposed by microorganisms. Polythene bags are synthetic plastics that are non-biodegradable and cause significant environmental pollution.

questions.question_text: A city is planning to reduce plastic waste. Which of the following actions best follows the 4R principle?

options.text: Burn all plastic waste in open areas
Reduce use, reuse bags, and recycle plastic products

questions.explanation_correct: The 4R principle (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Recover) encourages minimising plastic use, reusing plastic bags and containers, and recycling plastic products. This approach effectively reduces plastic waste and environmental pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning plastic releases toxic fumes. Dumping in rivers pollutes water bodies. Burying plastic underground does not decompose it as plastic is non-biodegradable. The 4R principle of Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, and Recover is the scientifically recommended approach.

questions.question_text: Why is rayon different from other synthetic fibres like nylon and polyester?

options.text: Rayon is made from natural cellulose, not entirely from chemicals
Rayon is the most expensive synthetic fibre

questions.explanation_correct: Rayon differs from nylon and polyester because it is made from natural cellulose (wood pulp) that is chemically processed. Nylon and polyester are fully synthetic, made entirely from chemical substances. This makes rayon a semi-synthetic or regenerated fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rayon is actually weaker than nylon, not stronger. It is not the most expensive and can be dyed easily. The key difference is that rayon uses natural cellulose from wood pulp as its starting material, while nylon and polyester are made entirely from synthetic chemicals.

questions.question_text: A manufacturer needs a fibre to make parachutes that must be strong, lightweight, and water-resistant. Which fibre is most suitable?
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon is the most suitable fibre for parachutes because it is very strong, lightweight, elastic, and water-resistant. These properties ensure the parachute is durable and performs well even in wet conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cotton and jute are natural fibres that absorb water and are heavier when wet. Rayon also absorbs moisture. Nylon's combination of high strength, low weight, elasticity, and water resistance makes it ideal for parachute manufacturing.

questions.question_text: Why are handles of cooking utensils made of bakelite rather than polythene?

options.text: Bakelite is a poor conductor of heat and does not soften on heating

questions.explanation_correct: Bakelite is a thermosetting plastic that is a poor conductor of heat and does not soften on heating. These properties make it safe for handles of cooking utensils, as it won't melt or become too hot to touch during cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is not cost, transparency, or biodegradability. Bakelite is used because it is a thermosetting plastic — it does not soften when heated and is a poor conductor of heat. Polythene, being a thermoplastic, would soften and deform at cooking temperatures.

questions.question_text: What happens when non-biodegradable waste like plastic is thrown into a water body?

options.text: It is decomposed by aquatic bacteria
It pollutes the water and harms aquatic life
It sinks and becomes part of the soil

questions.explanation_correct: Non-biodegradable plastics persist in water bodies, polluting the water and harming aquatic life. Fish, turtles, and other marine animals may ingest plastic pieces or get entangled, leading to injury or death. The plastic does not decompose naturally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic does not dissolve in water or get decomposed by aquatic bacteria because it is non-biodegradable. While some plastics may sink, they do not become part of the soil in any useful way. The plastic remains in the water, causing pollution and posing a serious threat to aquatic ecosystems.

questions.question_text: A fibre is obtained by chemical treatment of wood pulp. It has properties similar to silk. Identify the fibre and state why it is not classified as a fully synthetic fibre.

options.text: Nylon; because it is made from coal and water
Rayon; because it is made from natural cellulose (wood pulp)
Polyester; because it is made from petroleum

questions.explanation_correct: The fibre is rayon. It is not classified as fully synthetic because its raw material is natural cellulose obtained from wood pulp. Only the processing is chemical, so rayon is considered a semi-synthetic or regenerated fibre, unlike nylon or polyester which are made entirely from chemical substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon is made from chemicals, not wood pulp. Polyester is made from petroleum derivatives. Acrylic resembles wool, not silk. Rayon is the correct answer because it is made from natural wood pulp (cellulose) processed chemically, making it semi-synthetic rather than fully synthetic.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following fibres in order of increasing water absorption: nylon, cotton, polyester. Why does this order matter for rainwear?

options.text: Cotton < Polyester < Nylon; cotton is best for rainwear
Nylon < Polyester < Cotton; nylon or polyester is best for rainwear
Polyester < Nylon < Cotton; polyester is worst for rainwear
Nylon < Cotton < Polyester; cotton is best for rainwear

questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Nylon < Polyester < Cotton. Synthetic fibres like nylon and polyester absorb very little water, making them suitable for rainwear. Cotton absorbs a lot of water and becomes heavy when wet, making it unsuitable for rainwear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cotton absorbs the most water among these fibres, not the least. Nylon and polyester absorb very little water. For rainwear, low water absorption is essential so the wearer stays dry and the fabric remains lightweight, which is why nylon and polyester are preferred.

questions.question_text: Ravi heated a piece of plastic A and reshaped it into a new form. When he tried the same with plastic B, it did not change shape and instead charred. Identify A and B and give one example of each.

options.text: A is thermosetting (bakelite), B is thermoplastic (PVC)
A is thermoplastic (PVC), B is thermosetting (bakelite)
Both A and B are thermoplastics
Both A and B are thermosetting plastics

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic A is a thermoplastic (e.g., PVC) because it can be softened and reshaped on heating. Plastic B is a thermosetting plastic (e.g., bakelite) because it cannot be reshaped and chars when heated further, as it has already undergone a permanent chemical change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If both were thermoplastics, both would reshape. If both were thermosetting, neither would reshape. Thermosetting plastics do not soften but char on excessive heating. The observation clearly shows A is a thermoplastic (reshaped) and B is a thermosetting plastic (charred).

questions.question_text: Why is it said that 'plastics are a boon as well as a curse'? Which of the following best explains this statement?

options.text: Plastics are useful but expensive to make
Plastics are versatile and durable but non-biodegradable and cause pollution
Plastics are biodegradable but not strong
Plastics are natural materials that harm the environment

questions.explanation_correct: Plastics are a boon because they are versatile, durable, lightweight, and inexpensive. However, they are a curse because they are non-biodegradable, persist in the environment for hundreds of years, pollute land and water, and harm wildlife. This dual nature makes the statement true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is not about cost or strength. Plastics are not biodegradable and are not natural materials. The key point is the contrast between their usefulness (versatile, durable, lightweight) and their environmental harm (non-biodegradable, persistent pollution).

questions.question_text: A polymer is defined as:

options.text: A small molecule made from a single unit
A large molecule made up of many repeating small units called monomers
A natural fibre obtained from plants
A chemical used to dissolve plastics

questions.explanation_correct: A polymer (poly = many, mer = part/unit) is a very large molecule formed by the joining of many small repeating units called monomers. All synthetic fibres and plastics are polymers. For example, polyester is a polymer, and its monomer units are ester molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A polymer is not a small molecule, a natural fibre, or a dissolving chemical. The word 'polymer' literally means 'many parts'. It refers to a large molecule composed of many repeating smaller units (monomers) chemically bonded together.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about nylon is INCORRECT?

options.text: Nylon is the first fully synthetic fibre
Nylon is made from wood pulp
Nylon is used to make ropes, toothbrush bristles, and parachutes

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that nylon is made from wood pulp is incorrect. Nylon is a fully synthetic fibre made entirely from chemical substances. It is rayon that is made from wood pulp, not nylon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon is indeed the first fully synthetic fibre, it is strong and elastic, and it is used for ropes, toothbrush bristles, and parachutes. The incorrect statement is that it is made from wood pulp — that description applies to rayon, not nylon.

questions.question_text: Electrical switches are made from bakelite. Which properties of bakelite make it suitable for this use?

options.text: It is a good conductor of electricity and heat
It is a poor conductor of electricity and heat, and does not soften on heating

questions.explanation_correct: Bakelite is used for electrical switches because it is a poor conductor of electricity (providing insulation), a poor conductor of heat (preventing heat transfer), and does not soften on heating (being a thermosetting plastic). These properties make it safe and durable for electrical applications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If bakelite conducted electricity, it would short circuit — it must be an insulator. It is not transparent, flexible, or biodegradable. Bakelite's insulating properties and heat resistance make it ideal for electrical switches and fittings.

questions.question_text: Which of the following practices contributes MOST to reducing plastic pollution?

options.text: Carrying cloth or jute bags instead of plastic bags
Burning plastic waste in open fires

questions.explanation_correct: Carrying cloth or jute bags instead of plastic bags follows the 'Reduce' principle of the 4Rs. By reducing the use of plastic bags altogether, fewer non-biodegradable plastic items enter the waste stream. Cloth and jute bags are reusable and biodegradable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thicker plastic bags still produce non-biodegradable waste. Burning plastic releases toxic fumes including dioxins. Landfilling alone does not solve the problem since plastic does not decompose. Replacing plastic with biodegradable alternatives like cloth or jute bags is the most effective approach.

questions.question_text: Terylene and Dacron are types of:
questions.explanation_correct: Terylene and Dacron are trade names for different forms of polyester. Polyester is a synthetic fibre that is wrinkle-resistant, durable, and widely used in clothing and home furnishing fabrics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terylene and Dacron are not types of nylon, rayon, or acrylic. They are well-known commercial names for polyester fibres used in the textile industry.

questions.question_text: Which of the following items is made from a thermoplastic material?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic water bottle is typically made from PET, which is a thermoplastic. It can be softened on heating and reshaped. Electrical switches, saucepan handles, and fire-resistant tiles are usually made from thermosetting plastics like bakelite and melamine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrical switches and saucepan handles are made from bakelite (thermosetting). Fire-resistant tiles use melamine (thermosetting). A plastic water bottle made from PET (polyethylene terephthalate) is a common thermoplastic product.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a natural fibre?
questions.explanation_correct: Silk is a natural fibre obtained from the cocoon of the silkworm. Polyester, nylon, and acrylic are all synthetic fibres made from chemical substances derived from petrochemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polyester, nylon, and acrylic are all man-made synthetic fibres. Silk is obtained naturally from silkworm cocoons and is classified as a natural fibre along with cotton, wool, and jute.

questions.question_text: Why should we avoid wearing synthetic clothes while working in a kitchen or laboratory?

options.text: Synthetic clothes catch fire easily and melt, sticking to the skin
Synthetic clothes absorb too much heat
Synthetic clothes are heavy and uncomfortable

questions.explanation_correct: Synthetic fibres like nylon and polyester can catch fire easily and tend to melt when exposed to flame. The melting material can stick to the skin and cause severe burns. This makes them dangerous to wear near open flames in kitchens or laboratories.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concern is not about cost, heat absorption, or weight. The danger is that synthetic fibres catch fire easily and melt on exposure to flame. The melted fibre sticks to the skin, causing serious burns, which is why cotton or fire-resistant clothing is recommended in kitchens and labs.

questions.question_text: Rayon is a fully synthetic fibre made entirely from chemical substances.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Rayon is not fully synthetic; it is made from wood pulp (natural cellulose) that is chemically processed. Since it uses a natural raw material, rayon is classified as a semi-synthetic or regenerated fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rayon is made from natural cellulose obtained from wood pulp. Although the processing involves chemicals, the starting material is natural. Therefore, rayon is a semi-synthetic fibre, not a fully synthetic one like nylon or polyester.

questions.question_text: Thermoplastics can be remoulded repeatedly by heating.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Thermoplastics like PVC, polythene, and PET can be softened by heating and remoulded into new shapes. This property makes them suitable for recycling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Thermoplastics can indeed be remoulded repeatedly by heating. They soften when heated and can be reshaped. This is different from thermosetting plastics which cannot be remoulded once set.

questions.question_text: Plastics are biodegradable materials that decompose quickly in the environment.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Most plastics are non-biodegradable, meaning they cannot be decomposed by microorganisms. Plastics can persist in the environment for hundreds of years, causing pollution on land and in water bodies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastics are not biodegradable. They are synthetic materials made from petrochemicals that cannot be broken down by natural biological processes. This is why plastic waste is such a major environmental problem — it accumulates and persists for hundreds of years.

questions.question_text: Nylon is used for making fishing nets because it is strong and does not absorb water easily.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Nylon is an excellent material for fishing nets because it is very strong, elastic, lightweight, and does not absorb water. These properties prevent the net from becoming heavy and weak when submerged in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Nylon's strength and low water absorption make it ideal for fishing nets. Unlike natural fibres like cotton or jute, nylon does not become heavy when wet and does not rot in water, making it durable for aquatic use.

questions.question_text: Bakelite can be softened and reshaped by heating it again after it has cooled.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Bakelite is a thermosetting plastic that undergoes a permanent chemical change when first moulded. Once set, it cannot be softened or reshaped by heating — instead, it will char or decompose if heated excessively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bakelite is a thermosetting plastic, not a thermoplastic. Once it has been moulded and cooled, its shape is permanent. Reheating will not soften it. If heated to very high temperatures, it will char and decompose rather than soften.

questions.question_text: Acrylic fibres are preferred over natural wool because acrylic is cheaper, lighter, and available in many colours, but wool provides better insulation.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Acrylic is cheaper, lighter, available in a wide range of colours, and more durable than wool. However, natural wool generally provides better insulation and breathability compared to acrylic, which is why both have their own advantages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is accurate. Acrylic does offer advantages like lower cost, lighter weight, and colour variety. At the same time, natural wool is known for superior insulation properties, making the statement about both materials' relative strengths correct.

questions.question_text: A polymer is a large molecule made up of many small repeating units called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A polymer is made up of many small repeating units called monomers. The word 'monomer' means 'single unit' (mono = one, mer = part). These monomers join together through chemical reactions to form the large polymer molecule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'monomers'. Monomers are the small building block units that join together repeatedly to form a large polymer molecule. The prefix 'mono' means one, while 'poly' means many.

questions.question_text: The synthetic fibre that resembles silk and is made from wood pulp is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Rayon is the synthetic fibre that resembles silk in appearance and texture. It is made from natural cellulose obtained from wood pulp through chemical processing, earning it the name 'artificial silk'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'rayon'. Rayon is known as artificial silk because of its silk-like qualities. Unlike fully synthetic fibres like nylon, rayon is derived from natural wood pulp cellulose.

questions.question_text: Plastics that can be softened and remoulded on heating are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Thermoplastics are plastics that can be softened on heating and remoulded into new shapes. The prefix 'thermo' refers to heat and 'plastic' means mouldable. Examples include PVC, polythene, and PET.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'thermoplastics'. These are distinct from thermosetting plastics which cannot be remoulded. The term 'thermoplastic' indicates a material that becomes plastic (mouldable) when heated.

questions.question_text: Materials that cannot be decomposed by microorganisms are called ___ materials.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-biodegradable materials cannot be broken down by microorganisms. Most plastics and synthetic fibres are non-biodegradable, meaning they persist in the environment for very long periods and cause pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'non-biodegradable'. These materials resist decomposition by bacteria and other microorganisms. Plastics, synthetic fibres, and metals are common examples of non-biodegradable materials.

questions.question_text: ___ is the first fully synthetic fibre, known for its strength and elasticity.
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon was the first fully synthetic fibre, developed in 1931. It is known for its exceptional strength, elasticity, and light weight. It is used in ropes, parachutes, stockings, and toothbrush bristles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'nylon'. Unlike rayon (made from wood pulp), nylon was made entirely from chemical substances, making it the first truly synthetic fibre ever produced.

questions.question_text: ___ is a thermosetting plastic used for making electrical switches and handles of cooking utensils.
questions.explanation_correct: Bakelite is a thermosetting plastic that is a poor conductor of heat and electricity. Once moulded and set, it cannot be resoftened, making it ideal for electrical switches (insulation) and utensil handles (heat resistance).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'bakelite'. It is the most commonly used thermosetting plastic for electrical fittings and kitchenware handles because of its excellent insulating and heat-resistant properties.

questions.question_text: Which property of polyester makes it suitable for making dress materials?

options.text: It does not wrinkle easily and retains its shape
It absorbs a lot of moisture

questions.explanation_correct: Polyester does not wrinkle easily and retains its shape, making it ideal for dress materials that need to look neat and well-pressed. It is also durable and quick-drying, adding to its suitability for clothing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polyester is not biodegradable, does not absorb much moisture, and is lightweight — not heavy. Its wrinkle-resistance and shape-retention are the key properties that make it popular for dress materials and formal clothing.

questions.question_text: What does the '4R principle' stand for in waste management?
questions.explanation_correct: The 4R principle stands for Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, and Recover. Reduce means using less plastic, Reuse means using items again, Recycle means processing waste into new products, and Recover means extracting useful materials or energy from waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct 4R principle is Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, and Recover. This is the standard environmental guideline for managing waste, especially non-biodegradable waste like plastics.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of synthetic fibres over natural fibres?

options.text: They are durable, wrinkle-resistant, and easy to maintain

questions.explanation_correct: Synthetic fibres are durable, wrinkle-resistant, and easy to maintain — they dry quickly, do not shrink or get attacked by moths, and require less ironing. These are significant advantages over natural fibres for everyday use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Synthetic fibres are not biodegradable (a disadvantage), do not absorb sweat well, and are generally less breathable than natural fibres. Their advantages lie in durability, wrinkle-resistance, easy maintenance, and resistance to insects and moisture.

questions.question_text: Which of the following fibres is NOT derived from petrochemicals?
questions.explanation_correct: Rayon is not derived from petrochemicals. It is made from wood pulp (cellulose), which is a natural material. Nylon, polyester, and acrylic are all derived from petrochemicals obtained from petroleum or coal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon, polyester, and acrylic are all made from petrochemicals. Rayon is the exception — it is made from natural cellulose (wood pulp) and is therefore classified as a semi-synthetic or regenerated fibre rather than a fully synthetic one.

questions.question_text: Disposing of plastic by burning it in the open is a safe and environmentally friendly method.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Burning plastic in the open releases toxic gases and harmful chemicals including dioxins, furans, and carbon monoxide into the atmosphere. This causes air pollution and poses serious health risks. Proper recycling or waste management is the recommended approach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning plastic is not safe or environmentally friendly. It releases toxic fumes and pollutants that cause air pollution and respiratory diseases. The correct approach is to reduce, reuse, and recycle plastic waste through proper waste management systems.

questions.question_text: Plastics that cannot be remoulded once set are called ___ plastics.
questions.explanation_correct: Thermosetting plastics undergo a permanent chemical change when first heated and moulded. Once set, they cannot be softened or reshaped by heating. Examples include bakelite and melamine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'thermosetting'. These plastics permanently harden after being moulded and cannot be remelted or reshaped. They are different from thermoplastics which can be repeatedly softened and remoulded.
